Expectation1: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation1: You get a I04antic call I04om your I04iend whose car has broken down on the side of the highway late at night, and they need you to come get them immediately.
Situation2: They notice dust and mess building up and carry out more regular cleaning tasks.
Story: It was nearly midnight when my phone buzzed with a frantic call from Sam. His voice trembled as he explained his car had broken down on the highway, miles from home, and he needed me to pick him up right away. As his friend, I knew he counted on me, especially in moments like this. But as I hung up, my eyes fell on the living room—crumbs scattered across the carpet, dust gathering on the shelves, and the kitchen sink piled high with dishes. My supervisor had just warned me about slipping standards, and another complaint could cost me my job. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in: the urgent need to be there for Sam, and the unyielding expectation to keep the house spotless. My heart pounded as I stood in the middle of the mess, torn between loyalty to my friend and responsibility to my work, knowing that whatever I chose, something important would be left behind.
